channel.title: Physics (simple mechanics)
channel.description:
A man of mass 75kg standing on the equator is moving because of the rotation of the Earth.
a) What centripetal force is required to keep him moving in this circle? b) How does this compare with his weight? c) How would the reaction force with the ground be different if he went to the South pole? (assume the earth is a perfect sphere)
I'm not too interested in the answers because they are available to me. I am more interested in the working because I don't understand how to do it.

item.title: Physics (simple mechanics)
item.dc:creator: @MujaheD Radeon
item.description:
@MujaheD wrote:

Thanks guys, that makes sense.

Read full topic

item.title: Physics (simple mechanics)
item.dc:creator: @xx_matty_xx Justin Bieber
item.description:
@xx_matty_xx wrote:

The radius of your rotation decreases as you move from the equator to the south pole. When you’re at the south pole, the radius and velocity are both zero so there is zero centripetal force.

Read full topic

item.title: Physics (simple mechanics)
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

Radeon:

Also, why is the reaction force different at the South Pole?

Think about it, at the south pole you are just spinning around, not actually traveling any distance as the earth spins. Understand?

Read full topic

item.title: Physics (simple mechanics)
item.dc:creator: @xx_matty_xx Justin Bieber
item.description:
@xx_matty_xx wrote:

[quote=“eczema3, post:5, topic:344029”][quote author=yakman link=topic=440408.msg3236957#msg3236957 date=1276555246]
the radius of the earth is roughly 6 kilometers.
[/quote]
radius of Earth = 6 378.1 kilometres[/quote]he probably meant 6 kilokilometres

Read full topic

item.title: Physics (simple mechanics)
item.dc:creator: @eczema3 eczema3
item.description:
@eczema3 wrote:

yakman:

the radius of the earth is roughly 6 kilometers.

radius of Earth = 6 378.1 kilometres

Read full topic

item.title: Physics (simple mechanics)
item.dc:creator: @MujaheD Radeon
item.description:
@MujaheD wrote:

You guys were right, angular velocity is the way. I was confused because they didn’t provide he radius of the earth in this question and they normally do. Also, why is the reaction force different at the South Pole?

Answers incase you need them:

Btw Yakman, I’m sure you already know but the Earth’s radius is a lot bigger than 6km :D.

radius of Earth = 6 378.1 kilometers

Read full topic

item.title: Physics (simple mechanics)
item.dc:creator: @yakman yakman
item.description:
@yakman wrote:

You can easily get the angular velocity by realising that it takes 24 hours for the earth to rotate once.
They normally give you the radius of the earth on a crib sheet. Or you could commit it to memory that the radius of the earth is roughly 6 kilometers. (I have actually done that)

Read full topic

item.title: Physics (simple mechanics)
item.dc:creator: @xx_matty_xx Justin Bieber
item.description:
@xx_matty_xx wrote:

I’m guessing you need to know the rotational velocity and radius of the Earth. Is this given somewhere?

I did this question for G484 but if the velocity/radius isn’t given I’m not really sure how.

Read full topic
